docs.snippet: Congressional investigators looking into the collapse of Enron focused  yesterday on records related to the company's labyrinthine dealings with investment vehicles tied to senior Enron executives.    Enron's creditors, meanwhile, struggled to sor...
docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional investigators looking into the collapse of Enron focused yesterday on records related to the company's labyrinthine dealings with investment vehicles tied to senior Enron executives. Enron's creditors, meanwhile, struggled to sort out whether they should help keep the company operating or speed its dismemberment.
docs.abstract: Congressional investigators studying collapse of Enron Corp focus on records related to company's labyrinthine dealings with investment vehicles tied to senior Enron executives; company's creditors, meanwhile, try to decide whether to keep Enron operating by infusing more capital or to withdraw and thereby speed its dismemberment (M)

headline.main: Congress Is Zeroing In on the Complex Deals at Enron

byline.original: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and JONATHAN D. GLATER

docs.snippet: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Kenneth L. Lay, chairman of the Enron Corporation, misidentified the publisher of a book that praised the company. The book, ''Radical E: From GE to Enron -- Lessons on How to Rule the Web,'' was publis...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Kenneth L. Lay, chairman of the Enron Corporation, misidentified the publisher of a book that praised the company. The book, ''Radical E: From GE to Enron -- Lessons on How to Rule the Web,'' was published by John Wiley & Sons, not PricewaterhouseCoopers.
docs.abstract: Correction of November 29 Business Day article on Kenneth L Lay, chairman of Enron Corp

docs.snippet: In hindsight, there appears to have been ample evidence that Enron's board might not have been up to the job of preventing what is becoming one of the greatest debacles in the history of corporate America. Some directors had consulting contracts o...
docs.lead_paragraph: In hindsight, there appears to have been ample evidence that Enron's board might not have been up to the job of preventing what is becoming one of the greatest debacles in the history of corporate America. Some directors had consulting contracts or other business arrangements with Enron. Others were affiliated with institutions that benefited from gifts from the company or its chief executive, Kenneth L. Lay. But investors, even some of the most vocal shareholder advocates, had been all but silent about concerns now surfacing over the board's independence. Enron was even named last year as having one of the five best boards by Chief Executive magazine.
docs.abstract: Investors, even some of most vocal shareholder advocates, had been all but silent about concerns now surfacing over independence of Enron's board; some directors had consulting contracts or other business ties to Enron, while others were affiliated with institutions that got gifts from Enron or its chief executive, Kenneth L Lay; many of potential conflicts of interest were apparent in Enron's Mar proxy statement (M)

headline.main: Eyebrows Raised in Hindsight About Outside Ties of Some on the Board

docs.snippet: The swift downfall of Enron has contributed to extreme turbulence in the United States Treasury market in recent weeks, causing violent swings in interest rates not seen since Russia defaulted on its debt and the Long-Term Capital Management hedge...
docs.lead_paragraph: The swift downfall of Enron has contributed to extreme turbulence in the United States Treasury market in recent weeks, causing violent swings in interest rates not seen since Russia defaulted on its debt and the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund nearly collapsed in late 1998. Even though the exact makeup of Enron's large trading portfolio remains a mystery, traders said that the energy company had bet that interest rates would continue to decline because of continuing weakness in the economy.
docs.abstract: Swift downfall of Enron Corp contributes to extreme turbulence in US Treasury securities market in recent weeks, when signs of strengthening economy prompted movement out of Treasuries; traders who were still betting on lower interest rates were crushed and forced to sell even more, depressing prices and pushing rates up even further; trades that appear to have gone awry for Enron are believed to involve sale of hundreds of thousands of Eurodollar futures, which are frequently used to bet on direction of interest rates or to hedge against fluctuations in oil prices; graph (M)

headline.main: In Turbulent Bond Market, Enron's Woes Exacerbate Turmoil

docs.snippet: Earlier this year, most companies would have loved to have Enron's problems. Californians resented the energy trading company's huge profits during their energy crisis, and Democrats in Washington raised questions about Enron's influence within th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, most companies would have loved to have Enron's problems. Californians resented the energy trading company's huge profits during their energy crisis, and Democrats in Washington raised questions about Enron's influence within the White House and about the cozy relationship between Enron's chairman, Kenneth Lay, and Vice President Dick Cheney. Nobody seemed better positioned to thrive during the Bush presidency than this Houston-based apostle of deregulation. Wall Street was impressed with Enron's strategy of swooping into formerly regulated markets to broker contracts for natural gas, electricity or unused telecom bandwidth. The company was celebrated as a paragon of American ingenuity, a stodgy gas pipeline company that had reinvented itself as a high-tech clearinghouse in an ever-expanding roster of markets. Enron's push to force utilities into the Internet age with its online trading systems, at a seemingly handsome profit, became an epic tale of the dot-com revolution.
docs.abstract: Editorial on rise and fall of energy company Enron, which reaped huge profits out of California's energy woes earlier in year and now has seen stock crash amid serious questions about its bookkeeping; more than $1.2 billion in market value has vanished as result of controversial deal with private partnership run by chief financial officer Andrew Fastow

headline.main: The Rise and Fall of Enron

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation, trying to reassure investors that it has ample liquidity, began to repurchase all its outstanding commercial paper yesterday, using $3.3 billion it borrowed from banks by depleting its lines of credit.    An Enron spokesman ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation, trying to reassure investors that it has ample liquidity, began to repurchase all its outstanding commercial paper yesterday, using $3.3 billion it borrowed from banks by depleting its lines of credit. An Enron spokesman said that when the commercial paper repurchases are completed the company will retain more than $1 billion in cash.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp, trying to reassure investors it has ample liquidity, begins repurchasing all its outstanding commercial paper, using $3.3 billion it borrowed from banks by depleting its credit lines; says it will still have over $1 billion in cash; Enron shares continue to sink (M)

headline.main: Enron Taps All Its Credit Lines To Buy Back $3.3 Billion of Debt

docs.snippet: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Enron Corporation's efforts to reassure investors misstated the initial of its chief executive. He is Kenneth L. Lay, not W....
docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Enron Corporation's efforts to reassure investors misstated the initial of its chief executive. He is Kenneth L. Lay, not W.
docs.abstract: Correction of Oct 24 article on Enron Corp; chief executive is Kenneth L Lay

docs.snippet: With its stock still suffering after the unexpected departure of its chief executive, the Enron Corporation today promoted a top official in its core energy-trading business to be the company's No. 2 executive as it begins finding new leadership. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: With its stock still suffering after the unexpected departure of its chief executive, the Enron Corporation today promoted a top official in its core energy-trading business to be the company's No. 2 executive as it begins finding new leadership. Greg Whalley, 39, was named president and chief operating officer. Also, the company promoted Mark A. Frevert, 46, to vice chairman. Both will join Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman and chief executive, in an office of the chairman.
docs.abstract: Greg Whalley is named president and chief operating officer of Enron Corp; Mark A Frevert is promoted to vice chairman; they will join Kenneth L Lay, chairman and chief executive, in office of chairman; photo (M)

headline.main: Two Are Promoted as Enron Seeks Executive Stability

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation said today that it had concluded negotiations on a joint venture to build a $300 million regasification plant in the Jordanian Red  Sea port of Aqaba. Rebecca Mark, chairwoman of the Enron Development Corporation, said that n...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation said today that it had concluded negotiations on a joint venture to build a $300 million regasification plant in the Jordanian Red Sea port of Aqaba. Rebecca Mark, chairwoman of the Enron Development Corporation, said that negotiations with its Israeli and Jordanian partners had ended and that she expected the parties would sign an agreement in the next couple of weeks. The plant would supply Jordan and Israel with liquefied natural gas from Qatar, on the Persian Gulf, beginning in 2001.

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation of Houston offered yesterday to work on a compromise with an Indian state government that is deciding whether to cancel a contract to build a $2.9 billion power plant. Rebecca Mark, chief executive of the Enron Development Co...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation of Houston offered yesterday to work on a compromise with an Indian state government that is deciding whether to cancel a contract to build a $2.9 billion power plant. Rebecca Mark, chief executive of the Enron Development Corporation subsidiary, said Enron was willing to "do anything we can to address concerns" of the Maharashtra state government. The plant is being built south of Bombay by a consortium led by Enron that includes the Bechtel Group and the General Electric Company. The state has questioned the legitimacy of the bidding and contended that the consortium would charge consumers too much for electricity.
